repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Water Sector Project in the State
            of Sao Paulo

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Water Sector Project in
            the State of Sao Paulo in Brazil are as follows: overall
            outcome of the project was rated satisfactory, and the
            performance of the Bank and the Borrower were also rated
            satisfactory. Some of the lessons learned from the project
            are: 1) limiting rational project selection criteria to the
            Bank project is insufficient. The Bank strategy for
            introducing rational project selection criteria was limited
            to the Bank project. The rationality of other investment
            projects was to be achieved through the execution and
            application of a marginal cost and pricing study, a limit on
            increasing the investment program by more than 20 percent,
            and the assumption that the same selection criteria would be
            applied on the remaining components of the investment
            program as well. Although Companhia de Saneamento Basico do
            Estado de Sao Paulo (SABESP) after some delay executed the
            marginal cost study, it never applied its recommendations.
            The ceiling on additional investments was easily
            circumvented by presenting some optimistic forecasts; 2) in
            the case of time-slice investment financing; the project
            scope should be defined by value instead of physical
            composition. In standard investment projects, the physical
            scope defines the design and content of the project which in
            turn define its cost. In the type of project like the one
            financed under this loan, this definition is not meaningful;
            it was replaced by a value, which was set at USD600 million.
            However, the project description in the Loan Agreement does
            not include this amount, but rather defines the project as
            consisting of eligible subprojects and institutional
            development; and 3) political interference should be
            reduced. The long-term and sustained performance of a
            utility with competent staff like SABESP can be safeguarded
            only by separating the utility from the political
            administration and introducing competition and private
            participation within the context of proper regulation.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Water Sector Project in the State
            of Sao Paulo

abstracts.cdata!:
The Water Sector Project in the State of
            Sao Paulo is geared to support the Sao Paulo State Water
            Company's (SABESP) investment program for 1989-1993.
            The project consists of: (i) selected water supply and
            sewerage subprojects; (ii) engineering and consulting
            services as required for design and construction
            supervision; (iii) studies and technical assistance to
            strengthen planning capacities for planning, marginal cost
            analysis and pricing, reduction in costs, and domestic waste
            water pollution assessment; and (iv) institutional
            development to improve operations and maintenance. Compared
            with past programs, increased emphasis is given to sewerage
            works and to small and medium cities rather than
            metropolitan areas. While covering urgently needed extension
            of services, this project will strengthen the capacity of
            the state water company to carry out more efficient planning
            of investments, improved internal revenue mobilization, and
            increased efficiency of operations.
